newsitem.title: GERMANY: Allianz sees Nov ruling in Vereinte case. [CORRECTED 15:05 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Allianz sees Nov ruling in Vereinte case. [CORRECTED 15:05 GMT]

text.p: Allianz AG Holding, Europe's leading insurer, said on Friday it expected German and European cartel authorities to reach a decision in November on its plans to take over the Vereinte Holding AG insurance group.
An Allianz spokesman said it hoped to begin selling Vereinte health insurance products through its own sales network as soon as the expected approval for the takeover came through.
The European Commission in Brussels said on Monday Allianz and Vereinte had officially registered their intention to fuse.

Allianz announced its surprising plans to take over Vereinte fully in July after trying unsuccessfully to find a buyer for the group, which it had partly acquired as part of a package from reinsurer Swiss Re in 1994.

Allianz decided to sell its DKV health insurance unit to Muenchener Rueckversicherungs AG in return for a majority in Vereinte's health insurance unit, the loan insurance firm Hermes and other smaller holdings.
Cartel authorities in Germany had objected to Allianz's original acquisition of Vereinte on the grounds that it would give Allianz too large a role in health insurance.
Since DKV and Vereinte occupy first and second position in the German health insurance market, ownership of both would have placed Allianz in a monopoly position.
Allianz's spokesman said no direct lay-offs would be made during the takeover, in line with an agreement to protect staff which is effective through to the year 2000.
(Corrects to make clear that staff will not be dismissed, but it is not yet clear whether jobs will be lost).
A Vereinte spokesman said the agreement applied to all 7,500 staff.
